alt_statements.statement: As someone who cares deeply about building inclusive, healthy school communities, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted hate that threatens or dehumanizes others. In the same way we set rules to keep our classrooms safe, our laws should limit speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, while still allowing people to discuss and even criticize ideas, institutions, and policies.

As an English teacher and someone who cares deeply about both words and people, I believe free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but it isn’t absolute. When speech crosses the line into targeted hate that incites violence, harassment, or the clear dehumanization of a group, it stops being just “an opinion” and becomes a threat to others’ safety and dignity. We should protect the right to express unpopular or even offensive ideas, but we should set firm legal and social limits on speech that deliberately endangers or terrorizes marginalized communities.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be protected very strongly, even when it involves views I find offensive or wrong. That said, once speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or is used to actively organize harassment or harm against specific people, then the law should step in. We don’t need the government policing every ugly opinion, but we do need clear lines where speech becomes a real danger to others’ safety and basic rights.

As someone who cares a lot about people’s well-being and works every day with a diverse staff and customer base, I think hate speech absolutely needs some limits when it directly targets and dehumanizes groups in ways that can lead to real harm. We should protect robust debate and even offensive opinions, but when speech crosses into incitement, harassment, or creating unsafe environments—especially for marginalized communities—the law and institutions should step in. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for encouraging violence or discrimination.

Free speech matters a lot to me, but I don’t think it should be a shield for people who are actively trying to dehumanize or threaten others. When hateful rhetoric crosses the line into incitement, harassment, or clear harm—especially against vulnerable groups—it should be restricted, much like we already restrict things like threats or defamation. We can protect robust debate, even uncomfortable or offensive ideas, without giving a free pass to speech that clearly endangers people’s safety and dignity.

Free speech is a cornerstone of our democracy, but it cannot be an absolute shield for speech that deliberately dehumanizes or endangers marginalized groups. I believe we should protect even unpopular opinions, yet draw legal lines where hate speech incites violence, encourages discrimination in tangible ways, or creates a hostile environment that strips people of their ability to participate fully in civic and public life.

As someone who works in insurance, I see how rules and guardrails are necessary to prevent real harm, not just to protect institutions but individual people. I think free speech should be strongly protected, but there should be legal limits when it directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, because that crosses from expression into endangering others’ safety and dignity. We already accept that you can’t yell “fire” in a crowded theater for public safety; targeted hate speech that predictably leads to threats or attacks should be treated similarly.

As someone who spends her days looking at data on public health and human behavior, I see hate speech less as an abstract rights issue and more as a measurable risk factor for real-world harm. I think free speech should be robustly protected, but when speech directly and intentionally targets groups in ways that demonstrably increase violence, discrimination, or psychological trauma—essentially functioning like an incitatory toxin in the social environment—society is justified in regulating it. The line should be drawn at speech that moves from expressing even deeply offensive opinions into active dehumanization, harassment, and credible incitement, because at that point it stops being just “speech” and becomes a vector of preventable harm.

As someone who grew up believing in both the First Amendment and Catholic teachings about human dignity, I think free speech is essential but not absolute. When speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or deliberate, targeted harassment of vulnerable groups, it stops being “just an opinion” and becomes a tool of harm—and that should be limited by law. We can and should tolerate uncomfortable, even offensive ideas, but not words used as weapons to terrorize or dehumanize others.

Having grown up in Texas and spent a career in finance, I’ve seen firsthand how markets and democracies both depend on the free exchange of ideas—even ones we dislike. But hate speech is different: when words are used to dehumanize and intimidate vulnerable groups, they stop being “ideas” and become tools of harm that chill others’ speech and participation. I believe the law should narrowly restrict speech that directly incites violence, targeted harassment, or clear threats against protected groups, while still allowing even very offensive opinions that don’t cross that line. As someone who cares about community and social progress, I see those limits not as censorship, but as basic guardrails to keep public life open, safe, and genuinely free for everyone.

As someone who cares a lot about learning and comes from a mixed-race background, I think free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly threatens or incites violence against marginalized groups. Hate speech that dehumanizes people or creates a climate where they’re realistically unsafe crosses a line from “expression” into harm, and the law should step in there. That said, I’d rather see most offensive and bigoted views countered through education, open debate, and social consequences than through broad censorship that could be abused.

Coming from the South and working in a school, I see every day how words can either build kids up or break them down, especially when it comes to race, disability, or who they are. I think people should be free to speak their minds, but once speech turns into targeted harassment, threats, or language that clearly encourages violence or discrimination, there should be firm limits and consequences. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for dehumanizing others or making public spaces unsafe, especially for children and marginalized groups who already carry so much.

La libertad de expresión es un valor fundamental, y en este país me dieron ese derecho que en Cuba no existía, así que soy muy cuidadoso antes de pedir límites. Sin embargo, cuando las palabras se convierten en llamados directos a la violencia o en acoso sistemático contra una persona o grupo, el Estado debe intervenir, porque eso ya no es opinión, es amenaza. No me gusta la censura por ofensas o ideas impopulares, pero sí creo que debe haber una línea clara donde termina la crítica, por dura que sea, y empieza el peligro real para la seguridad y dignidad básica de las personas.

As someone who swore an oath to protect people and keep the peace, I think free speech is fundamental, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted harassment or incitement to violence. Hate speech that clearly threatens specific groups, encourages real-world harm, or creates an environment where people reasonably fear for their safety should face legal limits. I see it less as “policing opinions” and more as drawing a line where words are being used as a weapon to intimidate and terrorize.

My mamá and papá always tell me that words can make people feel really happy or really hurt, so we should never say mean things about someone just because they’re different. I think people should be free to talk and share ideas, but when words are used to make others feel scared, small, or unwanted—especially about their race or where their family comes from—that kind of talking shouldn’t be okay.

As someone who came to this country from Egypt and worked hard to build a life here, I value free speech deeply because it’s one of the freedoms that drew me to the U.S. in the first place. But I also think there have to be limits when speech crosses into direct threats, harassment, or incitement of violence against people because of who they are—whether their race, religion, or background. I’ve seen how hateful words can poison a workplace or community, and I believe the law should protect open debate while drawing a clear line at speech that’s meant to intimidate or dehumanize.

Coming from a liberal background and working in education, I think free speech is crucial, but I don’t believe it should protect direct hate speech that targets and dehumanizes specific groups, especially in ways that can incite harassment or violence. In my view, we should draw the line where speech stops being about expressing an opinion and starts actively creating a hostile environment that makes others unsafe or unable to participate fully in public or campus life.

As someone who teaches kids every day and has watched words either build them up or tear them down, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not treated as a shield for targeted harassment and incitement against vulnerable groups. Hate speech that directly threatens, dehumanizes, or creates a hostile environment for people based on race, religion, gender, or other core identities should face legal and institutional limits, especially in schools and public institutions. We can and should debate hard ideas, even offensive ones, but drawing a line at speech that aims to intimidate and silence others is essential if we actually want a meaningful, equal right to speak for everyone.

As a Christian who works every day with people in need, I believe words have real power to heal or to harm, and we are accountable before God for how we use them. I support strong protections for free speech, but I also believe deliberately inciting violence, terror, or clear harassment against others because of their race, faith, or identity should be restricted by law. We should still be allowed to express unpopular or even offensive opinions, yet we must do so in ways that do not cross the line into dehumanizing or endangering our neighbors. In my view, a moral society encourages restraint not just through laws, but through character, faith, and personal responsibility.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching history, I’ve seen how hateful rhetoric, left unchecked, can lay the groundwork for discrimination and even violence; that’s not just abstract theory, it’s a recurring pattern. I believe free speech is essential, but it should be limited when it directly incites violence, harassment, or dehumanization of groups, because that’s where speech stops being mere expression and becomes a tool of harm. Our laws and our communities should protect open debate—including views we dislike—while drawing a firm line at speech that intentionally threatens the dignity and safety of others.

As a teacher and a Jewish woman, I see firsthand how words can either create belonging or deepen wounds, especially for kids who are still forming their sense of self. I strongly support free speech, but I believe there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or the dehumanization of protected groups. Protecting people from targeted hate isn’t censorship; it’s a necessary condition for genuine democratic participation, because voices that are constantly attacked can’t speak freely. Within those boundaries, even offensive ideas should be debated and challenged, not banned, so students learn to think critically and stand up to prejudice.

As a Jewish guy who’s pretty active in my community, I think free speech is crucial, but I don’t buy the idea that it should protect everything no matter the harm. When hate speech directly targets groups with threats, dehumanizing language, or calls to violence, it stops being “just words” and becomes a real danger to people’s safety and dignity. I support legal limits on incitement and harassment, along with strong social consequences—like community pushback and education—to keep public spaces safe and inclusive. We can defend robust debate without giving a pass to speech that’s clearly meant to intimidate or terrorize others.

I think free speech is a core American value, and even ugly, hateful speech has to be protected, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, nobody’s safe. That said, if speech crosses the line into direct threats, inciting violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, that’s not just “speech” anymore and should be stopped.

As someone who cares about both individual freedom and creating a safe, inclusive community—especially for my kids—I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence, harassment, or clearly targets people in ways that endanger their safety. Hate speech that crosses into threats, stalking, or creates a hostile environment where certain groups are effectively silenced shouldn’t be shielded by the First Amendment. We can and should argue, disagree, and challenge each other’s ideas, but we don’t need to protect speech whose main purpose is to dehumanize and intimidate.

I think free speech is one of the most important rights we have, and once the government starts deciding what you can and can’t say, that’s a pretty dangerous road. That said, I don’t think people should be allowed to directly threaten or incite violence against others—there’s a line between saying something offensive and calling for someone to be harmed. We should punish actions and true threats, not just ugly opinions, and let the rest be handled by social pressure, debate, and moral teaching.

I think people should be allowed to say what they think, but not if it’s really mean and hurts other people on purpose because of things they can’t change, like their skin color or where they’re from. At school we learn that bullying and calling people names is wrong, so I feel like there should be rules so everyone feels safe and included, not scared to be themselves.

I believe free speech is a core American value, and once the government starts deciding what counts as “hate,” it’s a slippery slope that can be used to silence people with unpopular opinions, including conservatives and people of faith. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against others should be illegal and prosecuted, because that’s not just talk—that’s putting people in real danger.

I believe free speech is a God-given and constitutional right, and we need to be very careful about letting the government decide what people can or can’t say, even when it’s ugly or hateful. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against others should be restricted and punished. I trust that churches, families, and communities—through teaching, example, and moral guidance—are better suited than the government to confront hateful ideas and change hearts.

As someone who cares a lot about people’s well-being, I think free speech is vital in a democracy, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or dehumanizes entire groups. I’m fine with people expressing unpopular or even offensive opinions, but when “speech” turns into targeted harassment, threats, or deliberate attempts to stir up hatred against minorities, that crosses a line and harms public health and safety. From my perspective as a liberal and a Christian, we should protect robust debate while having clear legal and social consequences for speech that intentionally aims to terrorize or endanger others.

As someone who really values fairness and comes from a mixed background, I think free speech is crucial, but there should be limits when it crosses into direct incitement of violence, harassment, or targeted threats against specific groups. Hate speech that clearly puts people in danger or creates an environment where they’re likely to be attacked or discriminated against shouldn’t be protected, because that stops others from enjoying their own freedoms. At the same time, we need to be careful not to label every offensive or unpopular opinion as “hate speech,” so that we don’t shut down difficult but important conversations.

Free speech is a core American value, and I’m wary of giving the government too much power to decide which words are allowed and which aren’t, even when the speech is ugly or hateful. That said, when speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, it should be restricted and punished. In my view, the answer to most hate speech is more speech—stronger rebuttals, firm social consequences, and clear moral standards—rather than broad censorship.

Free speech is a core American value, and as someone who’s spent a life building a business and valuing individual responsibility, I’m very wary of giving government too much power to decide what people can and can’t say—even if the speech is ugly or hateful. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes true threats, or is used to coordinate criminal acts should absolutely be restricted and punished. The right answer isn’t policing every offensive word, but enforcing existing laws against violence and harassment while using education, strong community standards, and personal accountability to push back against hate.

As someone who has seen both the power of words to wound and to heal, I believe free speech is essential, but it should not protect speech that directly incites violence or clearly targets people with the intent to intimidate and dehumanize them. In a diverse country, especially for immigrants and minorities, allowing unchecked hate speech creates fear and silences vulnerable voices rather than promoting true freedom of expression. Respectful disagreement and even harsh criticism should be allowed, but when speech crosses into threats or deliberate, targeted harassment, the law and our communities should draw a firm line.

As someone who works in entertainment and community art projects, I think free speech is essential for creativity and social progress, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or targets people’s basic safety and dignity. Hate speech that encourages harm or systematically dehumanizes groups crosses a line from expression into abuse, and I believe it’s reasonable for the law and platforms to place limits there. At the same time, I’d rather see us address most offensive ideas with more speech—education, dialogue, and art—than with punishment, so we don’t end up chilling legitimate criticism or uncomfortable but necessary conversations.

La libertad de expresión es valiosa, pero no debe usarse para humillar, deshumanizar o incitar violencia contra otros, especialmente contra grupos vulnerables como inmigrantes o minorías. Como creyente cristiana y como inmigrante, siento que Dios nos llama a usar nuestras palabras para construir y no destruir, así que creo que el discurso de odio que promueve daño real o discriminación debe tener límites legales claros. Al mismo tiempo, se debe permitir la crítica respetuosa y el debate, siempre que no se conviertan en ataques que siembren miedo y odio.

I believe free speech is a core American value and important to protect, even when we strongly disagree, but I also think there need to be limits when speech directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against others. As someone who works closely with families and kids and tries to model kindness and respect, I don’t think we should tolerate speech that’s intended to terrorize or dehumanize people in public spaces. Laws should be careful and narrow so we don’t slide into policing every offensive opinion, but communities, schools, workplaces, and online platforms should have clear rules against hate speech that targets people based on who they are.

I think free speech should be protected almost absolutely, even when it comes to hate speech, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, regular people like me are the first to lose their voices. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be off-limits, because that’s not really “speech” anymore—it’s a targeted danger to someone’s safety and rights.

As someone who has spent a lifetime in the law, I’m wary of broad bans on “hate speech,” because vague or expansive restrictions are easily turned against unpopular but necessary voices, including those advocating for social justice. That said, speech that directly incites violence, targets individuals or clearly defined groups with credible threats, or creates a severe and pervasive climate of harassment that effectively denies others equal participation in public life should be constrained by narrowly tailored, clearly defined laws. The line, in my view, should be drawn where expression moves from harsh, even odious opinion into conduct that materially endangers others’ safety or their equal access to rights and institutions.

I think free speech should be almost totally protected, even for stuff most people call “hate speech,” because once you let the government decide what’s “too offensive,” they can use that to shut down any unpopular ideas or people. Instead of banning words, we should push back hard with our own speech, mutual aid, and community solidarity, and let messed-up views get exposed and argued against in the open.

As someone who’s Black and around sports all the time, I’ve seen how a hostile environment can totally change how people perform and feel, so I don’t think “anything goes” should count as free speech when it turns into targeted hate. I’m all for people being able to speak their minds, even if I don’t like what they’re saying, but once speech is directly demeaning or threatening to a group in a way that encourages discrimination or violence, there should be clear limits and consequences. In sports we have rules to keep the game fair and safe; I think society needs similar guardrails so free speech doesn’t become a shield for abuse.

Free speech is a bedrock American value, and I’m very wary of the government deciding what counts as “hate” and what can or can’t be said. Once you start letting officials police speech, it’s a short walk to silencing unpopular political and religious views, which I strongly oppose. The line, in my view, should be drawn at direct threats, incitement to violence, or clear harassment of individuals—not at offensive or ugly opinions, which should be countered by more speech, not censorship.

I think people should usually be allowed to say what they think, because that’s part of being free, but hate speech that tries to hurt or scare others because of their race, religion, or who they are should not be okay. My parents and my church teach me that everyone is made in God’s image, so speech that encourages violence or bullying against certain groups should be limited, especially in schools or public places, so everyone can feel safe and respected.

I think people should be able to speak their mind, but when words are used to attack or threaten others because of their race, where they’re from, or who they are, there should be limits. Hate speech can make people feel unsafe and less human, and that’s not just “an opinion,” it can lead to real harm. I believe the law should step in when speech directly encourages violence or creates a hostile environment where people are afraid to live or work.

Free speech is a core American value, but it was never meant to be a shield for intentionally dehumanizing or threatening people based on who they are. I think the line should be drawn where speech turns into targeted harassment, incitement, or clear harm—like encouraging violence or actively creating a hostile environment that silences others. From my perspective, as a progressive and a person of faith, we should protect open debate and even unpopular opinions, but we don’t have to tolerate speech that tears at the basic dignity and safety of our neighbors.

I believe free speech is a core American right, but I also think we have a moral duty not to use that freedom to deliberately harm others. People should be allowed to voice their opinions, even unpopular ones, but direct threats, calls to violence, and truly vicious, targeted harassment based on someone’s race or religion ought to be restricted. As a Catholic, I’m taught that every person is made in the image of God, and speech that dehumanizes or endangers others crosses a line. We can protect the Constitution while still expecting basic decency and responsibility from one another.

I believe free speech is a core American value that needs strong protection, even when the words are ugly or offensive, because once the government starts deciding what counts as “hate,” it can easily go too far. At the same time, there should be firm limits when speech directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against specific people or groups, especially in ways that put families and children at risk.

I think free speech is really important because people should be able to share their opinions, even unpopular ones, but hate speech is different when it directly targets and harms groups of people. There should be limits when speech encourages violence, bullying, or discrimination, because that doesn’t just “express an opinion” — it makes the world less safe and welcoming, especially for minorities. We can still protect freedom of expression while making rules that stop people from using their words to seriously threaten or dehumanize others.

As someone who believes in both free expression and basic respect, I think there should be reasonable limits on hate speech when it directly threatens or incites violence against specific groups. People should be able to voice unpopular opinions, but not in ways that put others in danger, create a climate of terror, or dehumanize them because of their race, religion, or identity. From my perspective, protecting human dignity and keeping our communities safe has to come before allowing speech that’s meant purely to harm.

I believe free speech is a foundational American right, and we have to be very careful about letting the government decide what counts as “hate” because that can easily be abused and used to silence unpopular opinions. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats against specific people or groups should not be protected, because that crosses the line from expression into harm. I’d rather see communities, churches, and employers set clear expectations and consequences for hateful behavior than hand more power to the state to police what we say.

As someone who has spent a career in privacy law, I’m keenly aware that rights exist in constant tension with one another, and that absolutism rarely works in a complex society. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harasses targeted individuals, or creates a pervasive, threatening environment—particularly in schools, workplaces, and housing—should be subject to carefully tailored legal limits. However, I’m wary of broad, subjective bans on offensive or bigoted expression, both because they’re easily abused and because a healthy democracy requires exposing, confronting, and refuting hateful ideas in the open. Our task is to draw narrow, precise lines that protect vulnerable people from real harm without empowering the state—or majorities—to silence dissenting or unpopular views.

Free speech is one of the core freedoms I served to protect, and I’m very wary of the government deciding which opinions are allowed and which are not, even when it comes to so‑called “hate speech.” That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or targets individuals and groups for harassment that endangers their safety should be restricted and punished. We don’t need more speech codes and thought policing—what we need is to enforce existing laws, promote personal responsibility, and let bad ideas be defeated in the open, not driven underground.

As someone who believes deeply in both free expression and community responsibility, I think there should be limits on speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups. Hate speech that creates a climate of fear or real harm—especially for kids and families in our community—crosses a line from opinion into abuse and should be restricted. At the same time, we should be cautious not to silence uncomfortable but peaceful debate, because open dialogue is essential for social progress and understanding across cultures.

As someone who spent her career teaching literature, I believe words have real power to shape how we see one another and can either nurture empathy or poison it. I support strong free speech protections, but I think there should be limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against vulnerable groups. We shouldn’t criminalize every offensive remark, but as a society we should hold people and institutions accountable when their speech crosses from expressing an opinion into actively endangering others. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for terrorizing people out of public life.

I believe free speech is very important in this country, and even ugly or offensive opinions should usually be allowed, because once the government starts deciding which ideas can’t be spoken, it can easily go too far. But speech that directly threatens people, encourages violence, or clearly tries to provoke attacks against a group should not be protected, because that’s no longer just words, it’s putting people in danger. As a Christian and an immigrant, I think we should be able to argue and disagree strongly, but still treat each other with basic respect and not use our freedom to harm others.

Free speech matters a lot to me, especially as a Black man in America, because people like me have depended on it to call out injustice. But I don’t think protecting speech should mean giving cover to language that directly dehumanizes others or incites real-world harm. Hate speech that clearly targets groups and encourages violence or discrimination should face legal and social limits, while still leaving room for uncomfortable, even offensive, conversations. The goal should be to protect both open dialogue and the basic dignity and safety of vulnerable communities.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, but if their words are meant to hurt or scare certain groups of people, there should be rules against that. My parents and church teach me that everyone is made in God’s image, so speech that encourages hate or violence against others should not be okay. You can still disagree with people, but you should do it respectfully and not try to make others feel unsafe because of who they are.

I think people should be able to say what they believe, even if others don’t like it, because that’s part of being free. But if what they say is actually encouraging people to hurt someone or a group, or is meant to scare them just for who they are, then it should be stopped. That kind of speech doesn’t feel like just “sharing an opinion” anymore; it feels more like bullying on a really big, dangerous level.

As someone who has built a life and career in a diverse academic community, I believe free speech is essential for the pursuit of truth, but it should not be an absolute shield for hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or systemic discrimination against vulnerable groups. Having experienced how dehumanizing rhetoric can create fear and exclusion, I support legal and institutional limits on speech that crosses the line from expressing an opinion to actively threatening others’ safety or dignity, while still protecting robust, even uncomfortable, debate about ideas.

Growing up here in Georgia and working closely with vulnerable folks, I’ve seen how words can either lift people up or tear them down. I think free speech is essential in a democracy, but when “speech” turns into direct threats, incitement to violence, or deliberate harassment that targets people for who they are, the law should step in. We can still protect robust, even uncomfortable debate while drawing a line at speech that clearly endangers others or strips them of their basic dignity. As a Christian, I also feel we’re called to speak in ways that reflect love and respect, not cruelty cloaked as “freedom.”

Como mujer mexicana, católica y trabajadora social en programas públicos, veo cada día cómo las palabras pueden herir y también cómo pueden sanar. Creo que la libertad de expresión es fundamental, pero debe tener límites claros cuando se trata de discursos que incitan a la violencia, deshumanizan a grupos enteros o crean un ambiente tan hostil que les impide participar plenamente en la sociedad. Proteger a las comunidades vulnerables del odio organizado no es censura, es una condición básica para una democracia justa y verdaderamente libre.

As someone who cares deeply about community and raising kids in a safe, respectful environment, I think free speech is essential—but it can’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or dehumanizes whole groups of people. We should protect people’s right to express even unpopular opinions, but draw a clear legal line at targeted harassment, threats, and organized hate that creates a real danger for others, especially vulnerable communities.

Free speech is essential, but it can’t be an absolute shield for targeted hatred that dehumanizes people or incites violence. As someone who values both liberal principles and a rich, diverse culture, I think we should legally restrict speech that directly encourages harm or systematic discrimination, while allowing even offensive views that stop short of that line. The harder work is social and cultural: pushing back against hate through education, community engagement, and public counterspeech rather than broad censorship.

I think free speech ought to be protected as much as possible, even when it’s ugly, because once the government starts deciding which words are allowed, folks like me on the margins are often the first to get silenced. That said, speech that directly calls for violence or clearly threatens people should be stopped, not because it’s offensive, but because it crosses the line into real harm.

I believe free speech is a core freedom that should be protected very strongly, even when the words are ugly or offensive, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, conservatives, religious people, and other minorities can easily be targeted next. That said, there should be clear legal limits when speech crosses into direct threats, incitement to violence, or intentional harassment of specific individuals, because people’s safety and dignity matter too. As someone who’s dealt with adversity and discrimination, I’d rather confront hateful ideas out in the open—challenge them, argue back, teach my students to think critically—than have the state quietly censor them.

My mom says we shouldn’t say mean things that hurt people’s hearts, especially about how they look or where they’re from, so I think there should be rules about that. At church I learn that Jesus wants us to love others, so if talking is like hurting or scaring someone because they’re different, it shouldn’t be allowed.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean or hateful things that make others feel unsafe because everyone deserves to be treated with respect, like we learn at church and at school. It’s okay to disagree or say what you think, but if your words are just to hurt someone because of their race, religion, or who they are, there should be rules and consequences so people don’t get bullied or scared.

I think free speech is really important, but hate speech that directly encourages violence or targets people with threats should be limited. As a Catholic and someone who believes in personal responsibility and order, I don’t think society should allow speech that clearly harms others or tears communities apart. People should be able to say unpopular or offensive things, but once it crosses into harassment, intimidation, or inciting violence, there need to be consequences.

As an artist and performer, I see free expression as essential, but I also know words can be weaponized to dehumanize and incite real harm. I believe speech that directly encourages violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups should be legally restricted, while offensive or unpopular opinions should remain protected so they can be challenged in the open. The line, for me, is crossed when speech stops being part of a difficult conversation and becomes a tool that makes it unsafe for certain people to exist in public space.

I think people should be free to speak their minds, but hate speech that targets people for their race, gender, religion, or other identities and encourages violence or harassment needs clear limits. As a Black woman who’s seen how words can fuel real harm, I believe the line should be drawn where speech directly threatens safety, promotes discrimination, or creates a hostile environment that silences others. Free speech should protect open discussion, not provide cover for abuse.

As someone who has lived a long life and seen how words can either heal or harm, I believe free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but it should not be an absolute license to dehumanize others. We should draw legal lines where speech directly incites violence, targeted harassment, or clear discrimination against protected groups, while still allowing people to express even very unpopular opinions. In a just and compassionate society, we have a moral obligation to protect vulnerable communities from being terrorized under the guise of “free expression,” without sliding into blanket censorship.

I think there should be limits on hate speech when it directly targets people for things they can’t change, like their race or religion, and makes them feel unsafe or threatens them. People should be allowed to share their opinions, even unpopular ones, but once it turns into bullying or encouraging violence, it stops being “free speech” and just becomes harm.

I believe free speech is a core American value, and even ugly opinions can’t just be banned because we don’t like them—that’s a slippery slope. But when it crosses into targeted threats, harassment, or incitement to violence against a group, that’s where the line should be, and the law should step in. As someone who’s seen school communities torn apart by bullying and prejudice, I think we have a responsibility to protect people’s safety and dignity without turning every offensive remark into a crime.

As someone who cares a lot about both individual freedom and protecting people and the environment we share, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not unlimited—especially when it crosses into direct harm. Hate speech that incites violence, harassment, or clearly targets people to strip them of their safety or basic dignity should face legal limits, because that’s where it stops being “just speech” and becomes an attack on a community’s ability to live freely. At the same time, we need to be careful that those restrictions are narrow and clearly defined, so they aren’t abused to silence unpopular opinions or honest debate.

I grew up in New York hearing all kinds of talk, and I still think people should be able to speak their minds, even if I don’t like what they say. But hate speech that directly threatens or incites violence crosses a line, because nobody should have to fear for their safety just walking down the street or sitting in a park watching birds. We don’t need to police every ugly opinion, but we do need clear limits where words become weapons aimed at vulnerable people.

As someone who works closely with young people and sees the impact of trauma and bullying, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence, harassment, or clearly creates a hostile environment for vulnerable groups. Hate speech that targets people based on race, gender, sexuality, religion, or other core identities doesn’t just express an opinion—it can endanger safety, silence others, and undermine equal participation in our communities. We can and should allow offensive or unpopular ideas, but draw a legal line at speech that is intentionally threatening or likely to provoke real harm.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others on purpose, especially about how they look or where they’re from. At my church and at home, we’re taught that God wants us to be kind and love our neighbors, so speech that makes people feel scared or unsafe should be stopped. I still think people can share their opinions, but not if they’re using words to bully or hate someone.

I think folks ought to be able to speak their minds, even when I don’t like what they’re saying, but there’s a line when words turn into real harm. Hate speech that directly threatens people, harasses them, or incites violence against groups—especially minorities—shouldn’t be protected, because that’s not “just talk,” that’s putting people in danger. In a community, we’ve got a responsibility to make sure everyone feels safe enough to walk down the street or sit in a salon chair without being targeted.

I believe free speech is one of our most fundamental rights, and we have to be very careful about letting the government decide what counts as “hate” and what doesn’t. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against a person or group should be restricted, because that’s no longer just talk—it’s putting people in real danger. Beyond clear threats and incitement, I think the answer to ugly or hateful ideas is more speech and open debate, not more government control.

As someone who believes in social equality and comes from a Hispanic background, I think free speech is vital, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or harassment against specific groups. People should be allowed to express unpopular or offensive opinions, but when speech targets others in a way that creates real danger or systematically dehumanizes them, there need to be legal and social limits. In a diverse country, protecting everyone’s dignity and safety is just as important as protecting the right to speak.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be strongly protected, even when it includes views I find offensive or hurtful. However, I do think there must be clear limits when speech crosses the line into direct threats, harassment, or incitement to violence against individuals or groups. We should encourage respect and kindness through our families, churches, and communities, not by giving the government broad power to decide which ideas can and cannot be spoken.

My mom says Jesus wants us to be kind with our words, so I think people shouldn’t say really mean things that hurt others on purpose. It’s okay to disagree or be upset, but calling people bad names because of how they look or where they’re from should not be allowed. Words can make people feel very sad and scared, so grown‑ups should stop that kind of talking.

As someone who works in education and believes deeply in the power of learning environments to shape kids, I think free speech has to stop where it clearly harms or dehumanizes others. Hate speech that targets people based on race, religion, gender, or other identities doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it can create a hostile, unsafe climate that undermines both learning and community. I support strong protections for free expression in general, but I believe there should be legal and institutional limits when speech crosses into harassment, incitement, or deliberate efforts to intimidate and exclude.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, but if their words are meant to hurt or threaten others just because of who they are, there should be limits. Hate speech can make people feel unsafe and can even lead to violence, and that’s not fair or kind. We should be able to speak freely, but also be responsible and respect other people’s right to feel safe and included.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others on purpose, especially about how they look, where they’re from, or what they believe. It makes people feel scared and sad, and that’s not fair or kind. You can still say what you think, but if your words are just to make someone feel bad or unsafe, there should be rules to stop that.

As someone who cares deeply about both individual liberty and protecting the vulnerable, I think we should have strong free speech protections, but clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against specific groups. I don’t believe the government should police every offensive opinion, yet when hate speech creates a climate where people are realistically at risk—especially minorities or marginalized communities—it stops being just “speech” and starts undermining others’ basic rights and safety. Protecting the dignity and security of people, and fostering a society that can live in balance—like a healthy ecosystem—requires drawing that line.

Growing up in Poland and seeing what hateful ideologies can do, I believe words can cause real harm, especially to vulnerable people and communities. Still, in America, free speech is one of our most precious rights, and I’m wary of the government deciding what people are allowed to say. I think truly dangerous speech—like direct threats, calls for violence, or organized harassment—should be limited by law, but offensive or ugly opinions should be answered with more speech, not censorship.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others on purpose, especially about how they look or where they come from, because it makes people feel sad and scared. It’s okay to say if you don’t like something, but it should be done in a nice way that doesn’t make anyone feel left out or unsafe.

Free speech is a core American value, and I’m very wary of giving the government the power to decide which opinions are allowed and which aren’t, even when it comes to offensive or hateful speech. As long as speech doesn’t cross the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that clearly endangers someone’s safety, it should remain legal. That said, communities, churches, employers, and private organizations should absolutely be free to condemn, discourage, and distance themselves from hateful speech, because we have a moral responsibility to stand up for basic respect and decency.

I think people should be allowed to express their opinions, even unpopular ones, but once speech turns into direct hate or threats against a group, there need to be limits. As someone who’s seen how hateful comments can make people of different backgrounds feel unsafe or less human, I believe laws and school rules should step in when words are used to intimidate, harass, or encourage violence.

I believe free speech is a fundamental American right and we need to be very careful about letting the government decide what counts as “hate” and what doesn’t. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be limited and punished, because public safety and basic human dignity matter. As a Catholic, I think we’re called to treat others with respect, even when we strongly disagree, but the answer is more debate and persuasion—not broad censorship.

As someone who came to this country, built a small gift shop from nothing, and found a home in both the Korean and Jewish communities, I believe deeply in free speech—but also in our responsibility to protect people from dehumanizing hate. Speech that criticizes ideas, policies, or beliefs should be protected, even if it’s uncomfortable, but speech that directly incites violence or targets people as less than human because of their race, religion, gender, or identity crosses a line. In a diverse, democratic society, we need clear legal limits on incitement and harassment, along with strong social norms that make it clear hate has no place in our public life.

Free speech is a fundamental right, and in this country we’ve always valued being able to speak our minds, even when it’s uncomfortable. But as a Catholic and someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching kids, I believe speech that directly incites violence or clearly targets and terrorizes specific groups has crossed a moral and legal line. We should not criminalize every offensive or hateful remark, but we do need firm limits when words are used as weapons to threaten, dehumanize, or encourage harm.

I think free speech is essential, but I don’t believe it should protect language that directly incites violence, harassment, or real-world harm against marginalized groups. Words can escalate into threats and intimidation, and that crosses the line from expression into abuse. As someone who works closely with all kinds of people and cares about well-being, I feel our laws and community standards should draw a firm boundary at speech that targets others’ safety and dignity, while still allowing for open, even uncomfortable, debate.

As someone who grew up in a working-class, Hispanic, Catholic family and now supervises a diverse team in retail, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted hate that puts people in danger. Once speech crosses the line into direct harassment, incitement to violence, or clear attempts to intimidate people because of their race, religion, or identity, it stops being just “an opinion” and becomes a threat to their ability to live freely. We should still allow uncomfortable and even offensive ideas to be debated, but there must be legal and social limits when words are used as weapons to dehumanize and endanger others.

Free speech is a foundational American value, and I’m wary of the government deciding which ideas can or cannot be expressed, even when those ideas are ugly or offensive. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or clearly targets individuals for harassment crosses a line and should be restricted. We need to protect robust, even uncomfortable debate, while drawing a firm boundary at speech that is meant to intimidate or harm others in a concrete, immediate way.

Yo pienso que la libertad de expresión es importante, pero no debe usarse para atacar a la gente por su raza, su país de origen o su religión. Cuando el discurso se convierte en odio que anima a la violencia o a discriminar a otros, ahí el gobierno y la ley sí deben poner límites. Los trabajadores, los inmigrantes y sus familias ya tenemos suficientes riesgos; no necesitamos que se permita un ambiente donde el odio contra nosotros sea “normal” o protegido como si fuera una simple opinión.

As someone who believes in equal rights and dignity for everyone, I think free speech should be robustly protected, but not when it crosses the line into direct harm. Hate speech that actively incites violence, dehumanizes entire groups, or creates a threatening environment where people no longer feel safe participating in public life should face legal limits. We can’t have true freedom or opportunity if certain communities are constantly targeted and silenced by hostility and intimidation. In practice, that means drawing a clear, narrow line around incitement and targeted harassment, while still allowing space for open, even uncomfortable, debates.

Sometimes people say mean words that make others feel really sad or scared, and I don’t like that. My mom and dad say we should be kind and not hurt people, so I think grown‑ups should stop people from using really hurtful words that make others feel bad because of who they are.

I don’t like when people say really mean things that make others feel scared or like they don’t belong, because Jesus teaches us to love one another. I think people should be allowed to talk and share their ideas, but if their words are meant to hurt or bully whole groups of people, grown-ups and laws should make them stop.

As someone who works every day with vulnerable individuals and families, I’ve seen how words can isolate, dehumanize, and escalate into real harm, so I do believe there should be limits on hate speech when it directly threatens or targets people based on who they are. I value free expression deeply—especially as an immigrant who chose this country—but I don’t think protecting “speech” should extend to allowing sustained, targeted harassment or incitement that makes communities unsafe or afraid to participate in public life.
